intro: Caraipa parvifolia, commonly known as the small-leaved caraipa, is a species of flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its simple, ovate leaves and showy, pale pink to white flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as cloud forests, and is often found at elevations between 1,500 and 2,500 meters. Its flowers bloom in clusters and are pollinated primarily by insects, making it an important component of its ecosystem.
